title: 5mm Z-axis spacer for my QIDI Tech 3D Printer

description.text:
This 5mm z-axis spacer was exactly what I needed to utilize the PRINTinZ Zebra flexible build plate on my QIDI Tech 3DP-QDA16-01.

My spacer is loosely based on the design used by this author:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1394527

Unfortunately, that one didn't work as the holes were too small for my printer so I whipped up a similar design which I printed at 100% in PETG and it was a perfect fit.

Now you can just measure the heel after grinding off the old wear and put measurements into the code.
It is work in progress, as I intend to buildin more variations, but the current code does what is described above.

  • Please 'LIKE' before collecting!
    Thomas
    www.3daybreaker.blogspot.com

These are the variables you can use:
Length, width en hight, they need no explanation
Further more you can ad a hole for a screw on demand
Furher more you can make the heel cone-shaped on demand
Thomas
www.3daybreaker.blogspot.com

This enclosure features a PIR sun sheild, 3D printed circuit board, and battery compartment with battery door. The circuit board is designed for an Adafruit Pro Trinket (5V) and Adafruit RFM69HCW Transceiver Radio Breakout. The exterior of the enclosure has raised digital camouflage type pattern and side handles for temporary mounting with small bungee cords. The PIR cover has a sun shield that also helps protects the PIR lens when transporting the sensor.

As always I have included the 123D design files you can use to make modifications to meet your project needs.

This is part of a larger project still in progress. This is being shared for others who may be looking for an enclosure for similar components. See http://www.instructables.com/id/Sensor-Array-and-Monitor/ for more of this project.

Thumb Screw Heads for the battery cover can be found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1764416

Digital Camo Stencils for painting can be found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1765630

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

2.6 mm

Infill:

30%

Remove support material and clean up any artifacts. All interconnecting parts should be cleaned up carefully and all parts test fit before final assembly. Holes should be checked and drilled to the correct size if required. Here is an Instructable I made on custom circuit boards:

http://www.instructables.com/id/Custom-Circuit-Boards/

Circuit Board: Assemble the components on the circuit board. The Pro Trinket can be attached to the board with small screws, but I used small pieces of filament melted on each end. I secured the RFM69HCW to the circuit board with a few drops of super glue on contact points. I wired the pins with wire wrap wire and wire wrap tool. The battery clip was soldered. The antenna wire strain relief can be glued on the printed board in the locations shown. I glued the wire into the notch on the top of the strain relief block.

Enclosure Top: The hole for the PIR needs to be cut out. The print has a thin layer with a wedge shaped support for the battery cover nut holder. Auto supports did not work well so I added these supports. They may be a little difficult to cut, so use a sharp knife and take care cutting this out. Put a 6-32 Nut into the battery cover slot on the top and two 6-32 nuts in the hex indents on each side for the side handles. They can be held in place with a few drops of super glue. Slide the circuit board into the enclosure top slots.

PIR Enclosure cover: The PIR is attached to the cover with fasteners. On the Adafruit PIR, the holes are very close to other components and be careful a metal fastener does not short any components. I used small pieces of filament melted on the ends to secure the PIR to cover. The PIR and cover can be assembled to the Enclosure Top using small metal screws. The Enclosure top has slotted holes for the screw to thread into, nuts are not required.

Enclosure Bottom: The bottom consists of the battery compartment and battery door. The enclosure is made for an 8 AA battery pack from Radio Shack. Test fit the battery door. It may require a little filing of the edges so the battery door works easily. There are hex indents for two 6/32 nuts. A few drops of super glue will hold these nuts in place. Press the enclosure bottom to the enclosure top. These do not need to be glued, they are held together by the side handles. The battery door can be held closed by a 6/32 x ¾” screw.

Handles: The two handles are screwed to the sides using 4 6/32 x ¾” screws. The handles also secure the enclosure top half and bottom half.

print_settings.Notes:: Springs require 3 layers and supports and the supports will need to be carefully removed.

title: Downhill mountain bike with dual suspension

description.text: This is a miniature downhill mountain bike with working front and rear suspension, wheels and cranks. The frame is all printed in one piece and then the other parts snap fit together. The front suspension is quite tricky because it is so small. While this is a working model remember that this is plastic so it is not very strong. You can download the individual parts here https://www.trinpy.com/models/downhill-mountain-bike-dual-suspension/

In my struggle to contain the wire and visual mess of my Kossel Mini printers, I designed this base.

Designed to fit almost any Kossel Mini style printer up to 220 mm build platform diameter, smaller sizes will work just fine as well. The use of brackets to attach the printer to the base allows very flexible sizes and configurations.

The model shows a Smoothieboard, though there is plenty of room for a RAMPS 1.4 or most other printer control boards in that space instead.

You will need a saw, drill and some patience or a CNC/ laser cutter for the top and bottom sheets that complete the base as well as the bed support and insulation circle. 1:1 scale SVG files are included for all of those pieces. You can either print them out and cut around them or load up your CAM software of choice.

Thanks!

Printer:

Kossel Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

25%

Parts List

*32x - M3 x 10 mm screws

9x - M3 x 12 mm screws

*4x - M3 x 6 mm screws

(*note that the screw lengths for attaching the top and bottom of the base to the walls assume you are counter sinking the screw heads completely, if not add an additional 3mm)

1x - 60 x 60 x 25 mm fan

Any will do, I like the quiet ones.
(https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B009NQMESS/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1)

1x - Inlet Module Plug

This one is more specific as it fits the hole in the back.
(https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00ME5YAPK/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1)

1x - Panel Mount B to B Female to Male Adapter Cable

(https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00FSYBKPM/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1)

1x - 2' x 4' 1/4" MDF Sheet

Any will do or something of similar material and thickness. This is used for the top and bottom sheets as well as for the bed support/ insulation if you so choose.

remixed_from.author: scarou
remixed_from.title: Compact Bowden extruder, direct drive, bearing bloc, auto load 1.75mm filament

description.text:
This is a remix of the excellent Compact Bowden extruder, direct drive, bearing bloc, auto load 1.75mm filament by scarou, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:669459 . I used his design for a long time with my bowden setup but I was having problems with my stepper motor "thumping" during fast extruder moves. Also, I was having the usual "ringing" and "moire" on my prints. Of course this wasn't caused by his model. So I ordered a Bulldog XL clone from Robotdigg and found their extruder lacking in a lot of ways. They don't use a hobbed gear and bearing like the actual Bulldog XL does, but rather, a cylinder type mk7 gear and grooved bearing. This proved to be an expensive lesson in futility as I had to exert a crazy amount of spring pressure on the filament to get it to work. I tried a hobbed gear and bearing setup, but still had to tighten the springs way too much. This brings me to scarou's design. I decided to try importing it into Tinkercad and possibly moving the filament guide to the right 3mm among other mods I did so it would fit on a 5:1 geared stepper. After about 6 or 7 prototypes, I think i have it. I've been using the new extruder for a couple of weeks and it works like a charm. I think I'd put it up against an actual Bulldog XL, it works so well. The only difference in hardware needed is (4) m3x35mm bolts to mount the extruder to the stepper motor because of the gearbox mount. Also needed is a 688zz bearing to support the 8mm shaft on the gearbox. This is very important. (2) m3x8mm bolts for the shaft bearing retainer. You'll also need a hobbed mk7 drive gear around 12mm in diameter. something like this: http://www.aliexpress.com/item/3D-printer-parts-Makerbot-Reprap-mendel-DIY-MK7-extruder-drive-gear-hobbed-gear-8-mm-bore/32244205970.html?spm=2114.40010408.3.7.1w2AHc and of course, a 5:1 geared stepper motor like this one http://www.omc-stepperonline.com/gear-ratio-51-planetary-gearbox-with-nema-17-stepper-motor-17hs130404spg5-p-140.html
You will have to shorten the tensioner springs by 5mm (if you're using the kind used for print beds). So far, I've tried PLA and ABS thru it with no problem. Going to try PETG and Nylon next. BTW, the ringing and moire have all but gone away! If you're using a bowden setup, I think a geared extruder is the way to go. Anyway, here is my Pitbull XL extruder and thanks again to scarou fopr the awesome design.

Note: There is a slight flaw with my design. The mounting bolt on the upper right under the levers is hard to get to. On scarou's original design, you could poke a 3mm allen wrench thru the mounting hole for the levers to tighten the mounting bolt for the extruder. With mine, the hole has moved, so, I ground down a 3mm allen wrench (as pictured) and slowly turned and tightened the mounting bolt. Sorry if this is an inconvenience.

Update: 7/13/16 - added recesses for left side mounting bolts on extruder.
Update: 7/14/16 - added link to 5:1 stepper motor

Extra hardware needed (besides the hardware for scarou's original design):
(1) 5:1 Geared stepper motor
(4) m3x35mm bolts
(2) m3x8mm bolts
(1) 688zz bearing (without flange)
(1) mk7 hobbed gear with 8mm bore (~12mm dia.)

Printer:

P3Steel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

30

Notes:

Printed wirh orange ABS
Built-in support for the extruder.

description.text: This is a quick vase design I made after seeing so many great geometric designs here on thingiverse. It is composed of nonagons that have been rotated from vertex to apothegm and scaled, repeated nine times, and mirrored. This generates a really (in my opinion) cool spiral effect that works with the sharper surfaces created by lofting. Thanks!

App.aratus is an app in hardware. It turns two iPhones into a stereograph for use with your home stereoscope. Update your old stereoscope to the digital age! Capture, extend, and share your vision with App.aratus. Suggestions for Use:
  • Turn both iPhone cameras on, functionally replace your eyes
  • Take and view 3D photos and videos
  • Print two devices and FaceTime between them - swap vision with friends and strangers in low-quality 3D!

title: Makerbot Replicator 2/2X Ramps 1.4 Conversion Upgrade Fix (Only $100)

description.text:
They said that it could not be done, yet here it is! Fix your Makerbot Replicator 2 for $100.

I have successfully stripped the Makerbot Replicator 2 of its true self and given it something better! I converted my Makerbot from the original 24V MightyBoard to a 12V Ramps 1.4 Board. It is fully functional and works better than the original (in my opinion).

If you are tired of using Makerware, dislike the Makerbot firmware, or have a dead Makerbot that has completely stopped working... this is a proven way to revive your 3D printer and transform it into a stronger machine for around $100!

I plan to add new things to this page as I make upgrades to my Makerbot.

Please use the comments section if you have any questions.

I came up with this idea because I have had a Makerbot Replicator 2 that has been running constantly since I purchased it in 2012. After years for non-stop printing and torture, this machine just died. One day I walked up to it and the screen was blank and all the electronics were dead. I called Makerbot to see how much it would be to replace the internals (the Mightyboard and the LCD screen) and I was quoted around $500 to replace the electronics. Now today, for around $500 I can buy a brand new 3D printer, so there was no way that I was going to buy new Makerbot parts. I’ve never really been a fan of the Makerbot electronics, Makerware, and Firmware because of the way it is a closed system that is not supposed to be tampered with or changed.

Therefore I came up with the idea to change it to a Ramps 1.4 system running on custom built Marlin Firmware and Simplify3D slicer. I have searched around on the internet for anything like this, but sadly was unable to find anyone who has done this same thing to a Makerbot.

First thing I did was rip out the Makerbot electronics. Now make sure to not throw them away. I took out my Mightyboard, LCD screen, Makerbot heater cartridge, and Makerbot power supply and then listed them on eBay. I ended up selling all of these parts for $300! Using this money I purchased all of the things on the parts list as well as a soldering iron, solder, glue gun, heat shrink wire protectors, electrical tape, and zip ties. From this point, I started building. See the "Instructions" tab for more info.

Parts you need:

12V 30A Power supply $20
https://www.amazon.com/NEWSTYLE-Universal-Regulated-Switching-Computer/dp/B00MAC9MO6/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1468378891&sr=8-1&keywords=12+v+30a+power+supply

Ramps 1.4 Kit - $30
https://www.amazon.com/OSOYOO-Printer-Controller-Stepper-Heatsink/dp/B0111ZSS2O/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1468378924&sr=8-1&keywords=ramps+1.4

External Thermocouple Board v1.0 - $16
http://e3d-online.com/Electrical/Components/External-Thermocouple-Board-v1.0

12V 30W Heater Cartridge - $6
http://e3d-online.com/Electrical/Components/Heater-Cartridge-12v-30w

Power Cable - $5
https://www.amazon.com/Prong-Universal-Standard-Connector-Cables/dp/B00F0UO11Y/ref=sr_1_4?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1468379543&sr=1-4&keywords=standard+usa+power+cord

Power Entry Module - $20
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B009180J44/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Jumper Wires $8
https://www.amazon.com/Honbay%C2%AE-120pcs-Multicolored-Female-Breadboard/dp/B017NEGTXC/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1468378989&sr=8-3&keywords=jumper+wires

Optional parts:

LED Light controller - $6
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00JRVSO38/ref=sr_ph_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1468379252&sr=sr-1&keywords=led+light+controller

LED Light Strip Kit - $28
https://www.amazon.com/LEDwholesalers-Changing-Flexible-Controller-44-button/dp/B0040FJ27S/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1468540573&sr=8-2&keywords=led+rbg+light+strip

I am not going to put together a detailed instructions list, but more of an overview of the project. I recommend using reprap.org for help. You can see how I put it all together in the photos. If you are looking into doing this to your Makerbot and have any questions about what I did, please just ask in the comments section.

Pre-Build:

  1. Rip out original Electronics. This includes the Mightyboard, LCD interface, and heater cartridge (located in hot-end). Make sure to leave all of the original wiring and connections left over from the Mightyboard. I use these to make wiring easier later on.
  2. Purchase all the parts on the parts list.

Building:

  1. Glue the 12V 30A power supply, ramps 1.4 board, and external thermocouple board to the bottom of the Makerbot. It is best to use the location under the bottom panel cover for the electronics so they can be covered up at the end.
  2. Using the jumper cables, connect all of the components into their proper places on the Ramps 1.4 board. This includes motors, end stops, drivers, heaters, fans, and the screen.
  3. Wire the ramps 1.4 board to the power supply
  4. Mount the reprap LCD controller to the front of the 3D printer. There are .STL files you can download in the files section that I designed to hold the LCD controller. Run the ribbon cables through the original hole to the ramps 1.4 board. Also, you can 3D print an SD card holder that will mount next to the controller for card storage.
  5. Using the external thermocouple board, connect the thermocouple cables to the external board and connect the external board to the ramps 1.4 board. You can see this in the picture mounted above the ramps 1.4 board. There is a more detailed explanation of how to do this here: http://reprap.org/wiki/ExtThermoCouple_1.0
  6. Install the heater cartridge into the hot-end. Note that the heater cartridge that I used is smaller in diameter than the original Makerbot heater cartridge and it fits in differently. A new heater cartridge is required for this build because the Makerbot originally runs off of a 24V system and uses a 24V 40W heater cartridge. This build uses a 12V system and a 12V 30W heater cartridge. If you try to heat up the 24V heater on the 12V system it takes about 15 minutes to heat it up to 150C and it will never reach the needed temperature to melt plastic.
  7. Optional: wire LED light board. I purchased the LED controller on Amazon. It came with a little plug in receiver and remote. I broke open the receiver open to get to the board. I soldered power wires and the RGBW wires to it. After it was all connected I then had control of the Makerbot's LED lights with the remote control. You can see this in the picture mounted below the ramps 1.4 board
  8. Remove the old LED light strip from the top of the Makerbot and install a new RBG light strip in the same place. I chose to add LED lights on the top, left, and right of the printer to make it brighter. My Makerbot LED lights only shined red, so I put in the new LED lights so I would have full control of color and patterns.

Firmware:

  1. I build my own custom version of marlin firmware. You can download a copy of marlin and edit it in Arduino IDE. https://github.com/MarlinFirmware/Marlin Once you have your firmware done, you can load it to the board using a USB cable. If you would like to try the version of marlin that I made, you can download it in the files section. Use it at your own risk.

Calibrating:

  1. After the firmware is built, it will need testing. Make sure everything moves properly and that the motors are set to the proper steps per mm and things like that. Do a few test prints. This will require a lot of trial and error. I got is done in about and hour.

Printing:

  1. You have now successfully competed the conversion to Ramps 1.4. Please share on this page and feel free to add any new things you may have discovered.

Resources:
I utilized reprap.org for the majority of this project. They have many helpful things about ramps 1.4, marlin, wiring diagrams, troubleshooting, and anything else you may have trouble with. I will put some helpful links below.
http://reprap.org/wiki/Main_Page
http://reprap.org/wiki/RAMPS_1.4
http://reprap.org/wiki/Marlin
http://reprap.org/wiki/ExtThermoCouple_1.0
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:87250
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:248181

description.text:
Pour over is a common way to brew a cup of coffee, it focus on well-roasted coffee beans and slowly extract the taste and flavour from the beans.
One of the most important factor to affect the taste and aroma is the ratio between coffee powder and water, some Japanese experts says that the best ratio is 1:10, 1g powder need 10cc of water.
Another way is Yamada-style, he extract only the first 1/3 of a cup of coffee. That is, only 80cc will be extract if we have 24g coffee powder. It made the measurement become important for a cup of coffee.
I made this pour over stand that could put coffee pot on the bottom of stand, and it has enough room to put electronic scale under the coffee pot.
The hole in the top could fit some popular coffee drip that I've, for example:

  • Hario V60 (1-2, 3-4 servings)
  • Kono (1-2 servings)
  • Kalita wave dripper 155,185
  • Kalita HA 101, 102

Thought I`d share this one with you guys. This thing is used to mount 3x digital to analog converter inside one case. Some reaming / tapping is neccessary. (M3x0.5) The converters DC power connectors (+5V) needs to be soldered together in parallel, I desoldered and removed the DC connector on two of the three converters. You'll only need one power supply (I can't guarantee that the one supplied with the converters is powerful enough to drive all three). Link to converters: http://dx.com/p/s-pdif-or-coaxial-digital-to-l-r-analog-audio-converter-44345 0.15mm
30% infill
225C
custom profile (filament diameter adjusted)
printed in MakerWare
Drawn in Solidworks

I made this for fixing the four tubes for the legs (or two X or Y) to grind them to the exact same length. The STLs are for 25mm IE conduit and M4 wingnuts, but I'm including the FreeCAD drawings so you can easily change to whatever needs you have.

First I was thinking about using ducttape, but then I realized that I've got this 3D printer and there must be a way to utilize it ;-)

You'll need one center and four ext (sides) for four tubes, or two ext for two tubes. (Aaand I just realized I'm an idiot. You'll need that per end, so all in all 2 centers and 8 externals)

Printed without support, 1.5mm walls, .8mm top/bottom, 15% infill. Havent tried them yet, I may tweak these values if they start cracking when tightening the nuts.

Update: Added a 10cm center part to use as a spacer as the tubes are able to twist a bit. Also printed with 25% infill, no idea if it does any good, nothing has cracked so far. I'm using PLA and a .5 nozzle.

description.text:
These are the first parts of my new printer project.

I am looking around for quite a while now to find the perfect 3D-Printer without any luck so far and today i started my own 3D-Printer project. I am using the ideas from the C-Bot and the D-Bot project and I'll call it the I-Bot.

I-Bot

The original designs serving as idea source and will be drastically modified. I am using Solidworks as CAD software. All files will be available for free as soon as they are finished.

Here are some of the features:

  • build size 300 x 300 x 300 mm
  • modified XY-Core system
  • option for 4 print heads at the same time
  • loading of four filament spools inside printer
  • custom STM32F4 controller board with modified firmware
  • open source firmware

This is a cut plan to crate a 10x12 inch round 'crate'. The example was cut in (surprisingly poor quality) 3/8" OSB using an 800x800mm X-carve with a 1/8" bit.

The x-carve Easel drawing is here:
http://easel.inventables.com/projects/C9rrlrylnvrGmf2XQ2BV-Q

The source SVG is also included. Load it into your tool of choice and scale it to be 1000x2000mm, using the included squares at those locations. Then remove the squares, set the cutting details, and arrange for efficient cutting. Note that the SVG does include holes in the top and bottom pieces, they just don't show up in the Thingiverse preview. The model is sized for "nominal" 1/2" material. Full dimensional 1/2" material might be a tight fit.

This is my complete Wilson II cable management system. Will work on other 2020 frame printers and adaptable to other printers.

Note: This will loose aprox 15mm of Z axis height.

My Wilson II is 50mm wider and 50mm Higher than the STD Wilson design.
http://community.reprapwilson3d.com/t/wilson-ii-plus-50/403/2

The chain is dragchain by TuxSoft, done in a customizer http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:915487

UPDATED: the holes in the X_motor_Nema_17_Wilson_Cable_Chain.stl where to large, this has been fixed.

UpDated; few extra holes on the X axis for cable ties

Added other number link files for the 8x10 and 8x20 chain links.

I use 2 x M3 cap head screws to join the X_motor_Nema_17_Wilson_Cable_Chain and Z_X_carriage_cable_chain_bracket together. I just screwed then straight into the holes as is. I used 1 self taper into the X motor ust drilled a small hole and screwed a very short srew in to hold it.

For the Y carriage I just drilled 2 holes off the part and used a zip tie. The hole is 2.5mm

My Printer I'm using

21 8x20 links for Z
24 8x10 links for X
22 8x10 links for Y

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Wilson II

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

35%

author: chev383

title: Clip mount adapter for Garmin eTrex Vista/Legend C/Cx/HCx GPS devices

description.text: In principle, all owners of a eTrex Vista/Legend C/Cx/HCx or similar handheld Garmin GPS device should already have such a little adapter that can be screwed on the battery cover and is needed when using the GPS with some sort of bike or car mount. The adapter is included in the standard product, while the mounts themselves are sold separately (or printed by yourself - see below). As it happens, such little things get easily lost. So, for all those who can't find it anymore (or managed to break it) here is a printable replacement. The printed part is fastened to the battery cover of the eTrex by means of a ~10mm long screw of type UNC 4-40. (Being in Europe, this is not an easy thread to find, but it turns out that this type of screws were used in the old 25- and 9-pin serial cables to fasten the plug to the socket - and some of those were still lying around in my cable box...) In addition to the parametrized SCAD file, I include two STL files - one for vertical and one for horizontal printing: The vertical version prints without any auxiliary support structures, but it requires a really good printing quality, since the layers are perpendicular to the flexible tongue, so with poor print quality, it will be easy to break the tongue when bending it. The horizontal version is much more robust as to print quality, since the layers are parallel to the tongue, resulting in a much better "bendability" of the tongue. In addition, since the layers are also parallel to the sliding direction, there is much less friction when mounting and unmounting the device. The disadvantage of the horizontal version is due to the need of some auxiliary structures needed to support the overhang of the tongue and the bridge on the bottom slide rail. These parts (shown in red in one of the above pictures) have to be cut away carefully after printing. Of course you can use this adapter also with my eTrex bike mount http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:163503 - which you can print yourself.

Given that the tongue has to be bent by about 2mm when engaging and disengaging the click-mount, I guess ABS is the material of choice here.  
I printed the adapter on my RepRap with a 0.40mm nozzle and 0.25mm/0.55mm layer height/width.

comments.text: Do you know what size and thread of bolt is required to attach the clip to the eTrex?
comments.author: viceroy176

comments.text: As I wrote in the main description, the bolt is 10mm long and has a UNC 4-40 thread.
comments.author: viceroy176

comments.text:
Do you have any tips for printing the upright version?
It's much cleaner but the tongue breaks very easily. How can this be avoided?
comments.author: poulhansen

comments.text: For the upright version to be strong enough, you probably need to print it with near 100% filling and you need to have extremely good bonding between the layers.  Also, if using ABS, "painting" the surfaces of the printed adapter with acetone-filament "slush" might help to strengthen it.  But even with this, it probably will never get the strength and flexibility of the horizontally printed version.
comments.author: poulhansen

comments.text:
Thank You
I just found out that I can get a reasonable clean item by sanding the bottom part, until the fastening brim falls of. Then I only have to clean the horizontal parts pointing downwards, that get a bit of "dripping".

print_settings.Notes:: Printed with ABS - PLA should probably not be used, as the rods can get fairly hot when heat bed is on, which could cause major deformations in the gantry - the rods I have retain heat very well, which makes this an even bigger issue. Printed at 0.015 for the best speed vs quality bang for buck. Since the part is only 20mm tall, infill is set much lower as anything about 10% is just a waste considering how surface area there is. There shouldn't be anything in the print requiring supports. The print is oriented as received in the STL.

description.text:
This is a redesign (built from ground up - so not really a Remix of a previous design) of chassis part designs for the Ultimaker 2 builds here on Thingiverse. I plan to upload as I finalize and test all parts. Currently there are:

Z Gantry Top Redesign
3-Way Norner Support

The first a redesign of similar designs of the top Z axis gantry for custom Ultimaker 2 based printers. The main motive behind this design was to allow the use of 12mm linear rods that aren't cut to exactly 339mm - I found that cutting the linear rods to exact length could end up in unusable rods or, if you were slightly over/under the measurement, you would get slippage of the rod while printing. My solution was to allow the rods to move through the support entirely, and to add a small screw hole lock the rod in place. Other features of this design are 1mm T slot alignment notch for easier and sturdier mounting onto 20x20mm extrusions, and a strong "brace" to prevent wobble and sagging. The design I had used before did not mount sturdy enough, especially around the rods themselves, and tended to have a lot of flex when the build plate was near the top.

The second, and many of the parts to come is a custom part specifically design to support the chassis for strength/durability, while also allowing for easy installation of 4mm acrylic/plexiglass for a all-in-one chassis/enclosure setup. As this gets closer to completion, I will be posting pictures of the actual build to show these parts in action.

As a final tidbit - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:811271 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1659579 are fully working designs that acheieve similar goals. Both are simple and relatively quick to print. My particular designs are meant to achieve a higher performance goal with 3D printer parts, offering more rigidity, easier construction, and the added benefit of a "drop in place" acrylic/plexiglass enclosure, of which exact dimensions will be provided and install instruction as well once they are ready! While this is a work in progress, if you are using any of the parts I provide, know that they are fully compatible with either of these other two sets.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 Clone - Omni Printer

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.150mm

Infill:

7%

Notes:

Printed with ABS - PLA should probably not be used, as the rods can get fairly hot when heat bed is on, which could cause major deformations in the gantry - the rods I have retain heat very well, which makes this an even bigger issue. Printed at 0.015 for the best speed vs quality bang for buck. Since the part is only 20mm tall, infill is set much lower as anything about 10% is just a waste considering how surface area there is. There shouldn't be anything in the print requiring supports. The print is oriented as received in the STL.

Screws used by this are M3 10mm screws. The part is designed to perfectly fit a 10mm screw being attached to a 20x20mm extrusion with a M3 T nut. Larger screws can be used,but will likely require drilling - but they can not be longer than 10mm. To keep the 12mm rods in place, the two screw holes will accept M2.5 and M3 self tapping screws. A suggestion would be to find a thin marker to mark where the rod meets the hole when installed, and go in and cut a small slot to accept the screw, but just setting a screw in there tight should do the job. If your ABS doesn't like the threading, an M3 insert nut can be installed using a soldering iron to alleviate the issue.

WIP: Once I get more of the chassis parts uploaded, I will created a more concise build instructions. For now, it is mostly going to be part-by-part or picture references.
Using AutoDesk Inventor. The inventor file is also included in case someone wants to adjust the screw length or hole sizes. All uploaded designs will come this way, so if used, please credit me. :)

description.text:
Added v2. Easier turning on track, smaller holes, rounded.  
Ballasting tools make the task of laying ballast on model railroads quick, easy, and clean. Unfortunatley, the tools to do it are pricy and overengineered. Here's a basic ballasting tool that does the job just as well. I plan to make designs for additional scales, but needed this in a pinch on my layout. Enjoy!

Simply print in place. Tool Instructions:
Place on track, and put in ballast. Run back and forth on the track to that the entire roadbed is covered. There will be additional ballast on the ties, but that is normal. Clean them up with a small paintbrush. Cement in place. Give the cement time to dry. Tool has been tested on Code 83 track with 18 inch radius sucessfully. Smaller radii (<18 inch) or smaller code track (like code 70) may or may not work.

comments.text: I really like this little tool.  Is there anyway to get one made?  I do not have a 3d printer and I do not want to spend a lot but I think it would work for me.  Let me know.

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Power Supply Backplate for 80mm Fan

description.text:
This is a back plate for the Wanhao Duplicator i3 Control Box and replaces the stock 40mm back fan with an 80mm Fan within an enclosed unit. Vents are directed towards the power supply, mainboard and centre of the power unit.

Print any 80mm Fan Grill, depending on the outer shape of your fan. For a square ending fan print http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:377656 and for a circular ending fan print http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:571272.

You can use the stock screws to attach the back plate and any 4 fan screws to attach the fan and grill. The hole in the top of the fan housing is for the fan power cables.

I also removed my inner 60mm power supply fan and cover and the machine now runs much quieter and super cool. If you do decide to do this, use cable ties to keep all the loose cables in the top of the box next to the mainboard to prevent them from hanging into the power supply.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

description.text:
Power Supply Holder

This holder is designed to hold a psu (power supply) to the back of a wall or to mount to furnitures or a piece of wood (see picture).

  • The bottom holder fixes the psu vertical in place and enables quick exchange or access to the unit.
  • The optional clamp will secure the psu vertical mounting.
  • For long term usage there is an optional top cover - without unscrewing this cover from the surface the psu can't be moved out or changed.

Supported supplies

Works with power supplies with the dimension (120mm width + 50mm height and any lenght). Example is a Nunus 24V, 17A, 400W PSU for 3d printers.

Supply size (cut off)

The cutout are made 121mm width and 52mm height [PSU SIZE] so there is a little gap for easier insert of the psu.

Ideas?

Leave a comment for further ideas.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

100-200 Micron

Infill:

10-25%

Notes:

All parts are designed to print without any supports and to save as much material as possible while retaining an air flow. The infill can be based on the used material 10 - 25%. For strong material like PolyMax 10-15% is fine.

If you use a 3d slicer where you can manually place supports you can add them optional to the side plates where the screws are fitted.
A follow up of my previous Doodles post.

Da vinci Junior

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1

90%

This is a replica of an ancient jewel, very popular and typical in the folklore of the region of Salamanca (Spain). Some people believes in its magic properties, and says it transports good luck... Its origins aren't well known. Some people says it is related to cowboys, other people says its related to some dark ancient wars or even darker beginings... But easy design in OpenSCAD, so I made a customizer to allow you to choose some of the properties and sizes of the typical keyring trying to maintain its original look. Do your magic, choose freely your design, but be warned!! not all designs have the same magic!!! Recommended configuration is a even or odd ball number between 8 and 14 according to that local region's custom manners.

So wherever you are you can print your own special and unique souvenir from the country of Salamanca's Spain.

Press Customizer button, launch the app and start the magic!!!
Included a Hi-Res .STL for twelve balls as an example, like in the pics.
Enjoy.

HINT: Should be cool a make in a shiny polished silver or gold metal embedded material. Painting balls should also be cool. On jewelery it's hard to make models with lots of balls. I challenge you to make the most complex and large printed model you can do. Like ancients say: Good luck and health for the rest of your life...

description.text:
This replaces the stamped sheet metal mount between Extruder and linear slide saddle of an UP! printer with a machined aluminum mount incorporating alignment features to reduce bounce in nozzle when short quick movement in print head occurs.
An added benifit is there is a lot less ABS getting scooped up and burnt due to the wobble of the extruder moving so quickly.

This needs to be made from machined aluminum or steel, I printed it once to confirm "Form and Fit" but for Function it needs to be metal. To get a more detail explanation please visit;
http://www.pp3dp.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=753 I've added a great picture from a friend of the before and after of how this will improve your printers performance.
http://pp3dp.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=841&p=6081&sid=bdcda38766bb69cabebddaaf28f79f59#p6078

UP! extruder Mofification
  • Tolerant to material variances
  • Stable mounting
    My best modification to the extruder has developed into;
    â€¢ Replace "pressure" block holding "fixed position" feed roller bearing that applies pressure to keep filament in contact with extruder gear with new design 2 part adjustable constant pressure block and arm incorporating "Vlier" spring plunger to apply consistent pressure regardless of variances in filament diameter tolerances.
This needs to be made from machined aluminum or steel, I printed it once to confirm "Form and Fit" but for Function it needs to be metal.

comments.text: What is the minimum gap between the bearing OD and the top of the gear teeth?
comments.author: strongcraig

comments.text: Mechanicaly it is less than 1mm with no filament present, but if you are asking this question I wonder if you understand what the design intent is?
comments.author: strongcraig

comments.text: I have used/modified a similar design that is printable. The big bearing I use precludes a filament sized channel close to the gear teeth. This is an issue with Ninjaflex that wants to buckle on its way to the nozzle. The other issue with Ninjaflex is that my 1.1mm minimum gap would not give the gear teeth enough bite. I modified my design and got it to extrude until the filament buckled due to not having a tight tunnel to travel in. Your design constrains four sides as close to the teeth as possible and the small diameter bearing helps with this constrained path. Not sure how close Ninjaflex needs to be held against the teeth as I overshot my modification and the minimum gap between bearing and teeth is 0.25mm. Have you successfully used Ninjaflex with your Up/Afinia printer with this mod?
comments.author: DrewPetitclerc

comments.text: I have tried ninja flex and it did not work, there is still too much gap around the feed gear and the aluminum block, allowing the filament to bend out, I need to get a longer PTFE tube to run up from my Recreus hot end and have it end against the feeder gear and pressure bearing to stop the bend-out.
comments.author: strongcraig

comments.text: I was able to stop the Ninjaflex bend out by carving out the side of ptfe tubing running by the extruder gear (no bearing required) then cutting the top of the ptfe to fit inside the chamfer lead in to the metal hot end. Unfortunately the hot end, as it heats up, causes a block just above the nozzle. I can print for 15 minutes before the clog if I start the print when the hot end is cold. I've contacted Recreus several times about an Afinia compatible hot end. Have not heard back. How'd you get yours?
comments.author: DrewPetitclerc

comments.text: Turns out I first read about the Recreus hot end on the pp3dp forum where you shared it as an option for Afinia/Up! printers. If you have an email contact at Recreus you can share, I'd like a real contact person rather than the form on their website which has yielded no response.
comments.author: strongcraig

comments.text:
Remember, to use the Recreus you need to make the mods I've listed here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:457420
As to a contact this is all I have,
Ignacio García
[email protected]

comments.text: points for effort, but think it might be a bit brutal of switching method using relay...maybe a great starting point is manual controls for temps, via resistor based switching and digital feed back in your box...keep up the good work!!!
comments.author: Ktronik

comments.text: Schematic is located in Thing Files...
comments.author: tomthul

comments.text: So your plan is to take complete control over the extruder temp via bang-bang relay control? I have reservations about this: firstly I think the Up's easily-removed support is due at least in part to software temperature control of extrusion temp at various points in the print; you will lose that. Secondly, with bang-bang as opposed to proportional control you'll have very poor control, with lots of overshoot and undershoot, depending on how much relay chatter you're willing to tolerate. No chance for PID with a relay.
comments.author: tomthul

comments.text: Also, the Up software is likely to complain (i.e. abort the print with an error message) if the temp it thinks it's reading from the thermocouple is too low or high compared to what it's calling for. Since your scheme completely divorces the Up CPU from temperature control, I think that's likely to happen.

description.text: Exported From LeoCAD
This is a pair of easily customizable glass whiteboard holders for markers and erasers. Customize this for the thickness of your particular brand of glass whiteboard.

I created this on a Makerbot Replicator 2.  The key is to make sure that the portion that connects to the whiteboard is the right width for your whiteboard. I printed this with the default MakerWare settings.  Please note that the holders are a little bit long and may warp. Using some tape on the platform can help. I also found that you may need to add a little glue to hold it on the whiteboard, especially for the eraser holder.

print_settings.Notes:: I was able to print this without support. You can try it with or without support.

title: Fidget Cube (with rounded edges now, remix)

description.text:
This is a remix of the best printing (and fun) "Fidget Cube" that I've found. Credit to Kobayashi!

I tend to print it scaled down 20% (16mm instead of 20mm for the smallest dimension is the smallest I'd go) or so. It prints well larger or smaller than the default size.

I was able to print this without support. You can try it with or without support.

I added fillets to every sharp edge so it feels better in your hand while "fidgeting". 3d printers are so good at creating sharp edges, that it tends to wear on your hands after a while. This one feels better.

Printer:

FLUX 3D Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I was able to print this without support. You can try it with or without support.
Break every joint free (carefully). I then used a lighter on each hinge, just long enough to soften the plastic and then started manipulating the joint. It makes it move very well.

comments.text: Great remix, printed great for me on my Replicator 2, smooth hinges. Printed without supports.
comments.author: Johnny__vegas

comments.text: What resolution are you printing? I had to print at 0.9x extrusion multiplier to get it to print properly.

comments.text: I printed this twice last year and it worked fine, but I have not been able to print it since without the hinges breaking when I try to move it. I have tried so many slicer settings and different filaments, but no help. Any suggestions of how to successfully print it?

comments.text: Very satisfying  to play with. I printed in ABS, cut support away with a hobby knife, and gave each side a quick blast with a heat gun (mostly for color). I did have to trim away some of the bottoms of the rounded edges to smooth them out.

This is my take on an infinity style photo backdrop stand. It has built in clips to hold the paper. I added springs to enhance the grip on the paper.

No support needed.

This is not a "remix" technically as I designed mine from scratch but it was absolutely inspired by the "Photographic Sweep Stand" by HPaul.

Also, I used a great chip clip design by srwilson58 and modified it for my purposes here.

I added "no spring" versions which just have the spring clip separated. You NEED to print the spring clip file ONLY if you print the "no spring" versions of the stand sides.

Printer:

FLUX 3D Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Just install the spring in to the bottom of the clip as shown in the pictures. If assembled correctly, the spring will align close to the upright. If it's installed backwards, it will stick out but still function just fine.

title: Spring and Ball  Rostock Dual-JHead effector assembly

description.text:
My dealings with these magnetic setups and their lack in strength, as well as relatively being very expensive, Has led me to this...

Still using the 10mm Ball-tipped carbon rods, but replacing the magnets with springs, and the cups are just designed into the effector-plate and runners.

much smoother movement with virtually no friction on the joints, and they don't pop off for the slightest of unhindered travel.

Kossel Mini

30 ~ 60 %

feed rate is the important part.

title: Space 1999 Space Station - Meccano Expansion Parts - Lost Plans

description.text:
These are the Lost Files from the Moon Base Station. Supposedly the Expansion Stations and Installations were Planned to be Built - but never were. Now the plans are found ! At least I found the Plans - maybe lost by me too ... Oh well , now they have been discovered by me !

Obviously, the Station Node Modules have Windows in the fore view , with Doorways in the rear. The Modules can be linked and screwed together in different combinations. The Tunnels can also connect the Doorways to other Modules (from rear or the endcaps) and/or to Central Towers.

These Tunnels are also meant to link to the Eagle Doorways.

Notice in Image #2, that you can peer through the Windows and Dooways Internally ...

Images #4 and #5 show the 1999 Eagle converted into a Tourist Ship, and Eagle linked up to a Space Station Ship, respectively.

Consoles, Equipment, Seating, and Personnel are left for the User to Install ...

Obviously, erector parts (including 3mmx10mm bolts and nuts) are needed to build Models with these printed parts.

Parts : Station Pod Nodes , Walls , Node End Walls , Plates , etc .

May want to refer to the Eagle 1999 Meccanno page for more Parts.

• Currently UNDER CONSTRUCTION *

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Mendel

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm - 0.8mm Nozzle Tips

Notes:

I printed these on a Mendel RepRap with 1.75mm fibre. I used a 0.8mm Nozzle Tip with 0.5mm Layer Height setting. Can use any tip from 0.2mm to 08mm should print fine.

It took between 3-10 minutes per part to print.

  • Walls and Caps need to be Rotated 90-degrees to be Flat on the Table to print properly.
  • Rafts are suggested for Large Nodes.
  • Parts may be a little thin and fragile - so be careful when removing.

Parts may have burrs and need filing to finish.
If the bolts seem loose, gluegun may help.
Used TinkerCad.

For MORE Parts , see related:

  • 1668780 - Space 1999 Eagle - Meccano Spaceship - Parts Model
  • 1686260 - Millenium Falcon - Star Wars - Meccano Expansion Parts
  • 1686914 - Mega Millenium Falcon X - Mutant Expansion - Star Wars - Meccano Expansion
  • 1666009 - Meccano Insect Robot - Parts 1
  • 1668041 - Meccano Robot Snake & Octopus
  • 1669029 - Meccano - Base Parts - Plates Struts Angles

title: Klipsch R-25C Center Channel Speaker Wall Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Updated 2017feb07: v1.0.1 fixes some calcs that prevented increasing mount tab beefiness, plus beefed it up from 3mm to 4.3mm just to be sure (plastic is cheap !). v1.0.0 models are still there for comparison but suggest to just go for the big'n. My original is still holding just like in the picture above, but one other person had theirs separate (although that could have been their print settings). Full details below...

// model: Klipsch R-25C Center Channel Speaker Wall Mount
// author: [email protected]
// date: 2017feb07
// ver: 1.0.1
// notes: Uses original speaker terminal mounting screws so no alterations to the speaker are required
// history:
// -1.0.1 - 2017feb07 - Fixed incorrect calculation that resulted in mountingTab being thinner than expected
// - Increased mountingTabThickness from default 3 to 4.3 to ensure adequate strength when
// installing with long mounting screw (to get it to angle downward) which could pull
// layers apart from the unexpected increased horizontal load
// -1.0.0 - 2015jul11 - Released

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0fwAMgrbJJg

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple White

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100%

Notes:

If printing taperred, suggest 100 micron and 200 micron for flat version.

Enable supports everywhere then scrape them out through the screwHeadHole

If using Simplify3D, set support resolution of 2mm and preview to ensure support is oriented at right angle to the screw slot. If it isn't, change Support Infill Angle value by 90 deg (default is 0).

create the front with 123D

At first created a spline line on the ground. Make a rectangle 1.5 x 1.5mm in 90 degreee to the rule. With "sweep" command make soild 1.5 x 1.5mm line with the rectangle on the line. Make a straight square 1.5 x 1.5mm block line in distance of 12mm to the ground. The curved front is created then with the "loft" command.

description.text: Spirt Cats Clan faction emblem from MechWarrior and Battletech universe.

Printer:

XYZPrinting Davinci 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

One nice feature of the DaVinci (if any) is that you can pause printing and swap filament. That is what I did here, printing the emblem in white until the detail began to print, at which point I switched to the light blue.

This is a key that fits into the mounts for the GoPro (and other cameras) that stops the sides of the mount moving to allow it to slip free. When printed it should be a press fit and can easily be removed by simply lifting the tab. Hope it helps other builders/pilots/video buffs.

Happy printing!

comments.text: What kind of filament did you use? Just regular pla or abs, or flexible filament.
comments.author: MatthijsJordense

comments.text: For anything like this where it needs a bit of flex and extra strength then ABS is my first choice. Other less brittle filaments like PLA+ will work too. You can use regular PLA and it should be fine but may snap if too much force is applied. Best of luck!

comments.author: coldfire3000

description.text: Fred Prototype based on his info and drawing, I corrected the round shape to match 7.25 inch diameter objects.

Update 2017-10-21
v3 added. These have thicker backplates (3mm vs 2mm) and connecting walls (3mm vs 1.6mm) for improved stability.

Due to the popularity of my pegboard mountable Screwdriver holder, I decided to also share this one that I made in the same style. It is a holder for standard 1/4" hex bits, the kind that you find in practically every toolbox. The funnel shape guides the bits and makes them extremely easy to place in the right position.

Adapted for both metric (12mm) and imperial (1") center hole distance pegboards, can also be mounted directly on a wall, pinboard or table edge.

The larger rear row is designed for larger bits such as countersink, chamfer, deburring and drill bits. The smaller front row is for standard screwdriver bits which can be placed closely together.

I also made a number of separate versions to fit everyone's needs; X in file name indicates number of bits. Photos show the COMBO version, printed in PLA, 0.15 layer height at 110mm/s.

No supports or rafts needed.

More tool holders can be found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/FrankLumien/collections/pegboard-and-tool-accessories

comments.text:
Very good design!
I printed one but after a few weeks it broke in the back plate.
Could you increase the thickness of the support on the back?
comments.author: Rudolf43

comments.text: Hi Rudolf, thanks for your comment! I've finally gotten some time to adress this. Version 3 is now available for all designs with 50% thicker back plate. If strength is an issue you might also want to increase the infill. I've used version 2 for over a year, printed with 50% infill (IIRC) and have not had any problems with breaking. Hope the new version works for you!
comments.author: Rudolf43

print_settings.Notes:: Extra shells can help to make sure it is water tight, 3 should be fine

title: Bottle Filling Station and Funnel for 2oz Boston Rounds Sample Bottles

description.text:
Filling Station for filling sample bottles, perfectly fits the 2oz boston rounds available on amazon. Great for sending samples of your favorite liquids to friends.

Two version, version 2b has no back, version 3 has a back. I prefer 2b personally since it is easier to see the fill level as you are pouring, but version 3 is a bit more stable.

See my other creations for a draining station for these same bottles.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

No

Resolution:

200um

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Extra shells can help to make sure it is water tight, 3 should be fine

title: Bottle draining station for 2oz boston rounds sample bottles

description.text:
Bottle draining station for 2oz boston rounds bottles available on amazon. After rinsing with water (never use soap! impossible to get all the bubbles out) place the bottles upside down in this to allow them to completely dry.

See my other creations for a bottle filling station and funnel for these same 2oz bottles.
